definition: to drag sb before a public meeting to denounce, humiliate and physically abuse them (esp. during the Cultural Revolution)
to ascertain/to act on/to criticize/to pass on/classifier for batches, lots, military flights/tier (for the ranking of universities and colleges)
abbr. for the Big Dipper constellation 北斗星[Bei3 dou3 xing1]
to fight/to struggle/to condemn/to censure/to contend/to put together/coming together
dry measure for grain equal to ten 升[sheng1] or one-tenth of a 石[dan4]/decaliter/peck/cup or dipper shaped object/old variant of 陡[dou3]

sentences.english: One part of critical thinking is distinguishing between facts and opinions.
sentences.chinese: 批斗性思考的一部分就是区分事实和观点。

sentences.english: Seem to be, a bitter fight begins.
sentences.chinese: 似乎，一场狠狠的批斗就要开始了。

sentences.english: Red Guards swarmed there for ritual denunciations of Liu and his ilk.
sentences.chinese: 无数红卫兵在这里给刘及其同类人开批斗大会。

sentences.english: But according to South Korean media, the players got off lightly.
sentences.chinese: 但据韩国媒体称，球员们还是很轻松地走出批斗会的。

sentences.english: If you didn't follow the Red Guards maybe one day they would criticize you.
sentences.chinese: 如果不追随红卫兵的话，或许有一天他们回来批斗你。

sentences.english: Because his grandfather was a landlord, he had been denounced.
sentences.chinese: 因为祖父曾是地主，他受到了批斗。

definition: capitalist roader (person in power taking the capitalist road, a political label often pinned on cadres by the Red Guards during the Cultural Revolution)
to seize and subject to public criticism (form of persecution during the Cultural Revolution)
Cultural Revolution (1966-76)/abbr. for 文化大革命[Wen2 hua4 Da4 ge2 ming4]
stinking intellectual (contemptuous term for educated people during the Cultural Revolution)
Gang of Four: Jiang Qing 江青, Zhang Chunqiao 張春橋, Yao Wenyuan 姚文元, Wang Hongwen 王洪文, who served as scapegoats for the excesses of the cultural revolution
abbr. for 勞動改造|劳动改造[lao2 dong4 gai3 zao4]/reform through labor/laogai (prison camp)

(category defined by the Communist Party) poor and lower-middle peasants: farmers who, before land reform, possessed little or no land (poor peasants) and those who were barely able to support themselves with their own land (lower-middle peasants)
